ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: DATA=SAS-data-set] 
      
Names the SAS data set to be used by PROC HPMIXED. The default is the most recently 
created data set.
Determines the computation of information criteria in the "Fit Statistics" table.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: For models with random effects, the number of parameters in the optimization whose solutions do not  fall on the boundary or are otherwise constrained is incremented by rank(X).

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies the maximum levels of CLASS variables to print in the ODS table "ClassLevels."

[Syntax: MAXCLPRINT=number] 
      
Specifies the maximum levels of CLASS variables to print in the ODS table "ClassLevels." 
The default value is 20. MAXCLPRINT=0 enables you to print all levels of each CLASS variable.

Specifies the estimation method for the covariance parameters.  There is no other 
choice at this experimental stage.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: The REML specification performs residual (restricted) maximum likelihood, and it is the default method.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata: Displays coefficients of the mixed model equations.

[Syntax: NAMELEN=number] 
      
Specifies the length to which long effect names are shortened. The default and 
minimum value is 20.

[Syntax: NOCLPRINT<=number>] 
      
Suppresses the display of the "Class Level Information" table if you do not specify 
number. If you do specify number, only levels with totals that are less than number 
are listed in the table.

Suppresses fitting of the model. When the NOFIT option is in effect, PROC HPMIXED produces the "Model 
Information," "Class Level Information," "Number of Observations," "Dimensions," and "Descriptive 
Statistics" tables.

Suppresses the display of the "Model Information," "Number of Observations," and 
"Dimensions" tables.
Suppresses the display of the "Iteration History" table.
Suppresses the normal display of results.
Includes the residual variance as one of the covariance parameters in the optimization iterations.
Specifies the sorting order for the levels of all CLASS variables. The default is ORDER=FORMATTED.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Levels sorted by the order of appearance in the input data set.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Levels sorted by the external formatted value, except for numeric variables with no explicit  format, which are sorted by their unformatted (internal) value.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Levels sorted by the descending frequency count; levels with the most observations come first  in the order.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Levels sorted by the unformatted value.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: SINGCHOL=number] 
      
Tunes the singularity criterion in Cholesky decompositions. The default is 1E6 times 
the machine epsilon; this product is approximately 1E-10 on most computers.

[Syntax: SINGRES=number] 
      
Sets the tolerance for which the residual variance is considered to be zero. The default 
is 1E4 times the machine epsilon; this product is approximately 1E-12 on most computers.

[Syntax: SINGULAR=number] 
      
Tunes the general singularity criterion applied by the HPMIXED procedure in divisions and 
inversions. The default is 1E4 times the machine epsilon; this product is approximately 
1E-12 on most computers.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies that class levels should be determined by using no more than the first 16 characters 
of the formatted values of CLASS variables.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: BY <DESCENDING> variable-1 <...<DESCENDING> variable-n> <NOTSORTED>; 
      
You can specify a BY statement with PROC HPMIXED to obtain separate analyses on 
observations in groups that are defined by the BY variables. When a BY statement 
appears, the procedure expects the input data set to be sorted in order of the BY 
variables. If you specify more than one BY statement, only the last one specified 
is used.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies that the observations are sorted in descending order by the variable that 
immediately follows the word DESCENDING in the BY statement.
Specifies that observations are not necessarily sorted in alphabetic or numeric order.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: ID variables ; 
    
The ID statement specifies which variables from the input data set are to be included in the OUT= 
data sets from the OUTPUT statement. If you do not specify an ID statement, then all variables are 
included in these data sets.

Syntax: WEIGHT variable;
      
The WEIGHT statement replaces R with W^(-1/2)RW^(-1/2), where W is a diagonal matrix containing the 
weights. Observations with nonpositive or missing weights are not included in the resulting PROC 
HPMIXED analysis. If a WEIGHT statement is not included, all observations used in the analysis are 
assigned a weight of 1.

Syntax: CONTRAST ’label’ contrast-specification <, contrast-specification> <, ...> </ options> ; 

The CONTRAST statement provides a mechanism for obtaining custom hypothesis tests.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Requests that chi-square tests be performed in addition to any F tests.
Requests that the L matrix coefficients for the contrast be displayed.

[Syntax: DF=number] 
          
Specifies the denominator degrees of freedom for the F test.

[Syntax: GROUP coeffs] 
          
Sets up random-effect contrasts between different groups when a GROUP variable 
appears in the RANDOM statement.

[Syntax: SINGULAR=number] 
          
Tunes the estimability checking.

[Syntax: SUBJECT coeffs] 
          
Sets up random-effect contrasts between different subjects when a SUBJECT= 
variable appears in the RANDOM statement.

[Syntax: ALPHA=number] 
   
Requests that a t-type confidence interval be constructed with confidence 
level 1-number. The value of number must be between 0 and 1 exclusively; 
the default is 0.05.

Requests that t-type confidence limits be constructed. If DDFM=NONE and you do not 
specify degrees of freedom with the DF= option, PROC HPMIXED uses infinite degrees 
of freedom, essentially computing a z interval. The confidence level is 0.95 by 
default.

[Syntax: DIVISOR=number] 
          
Specifies a value by which to divide all coefficients so that fractional coefficients 
can be entered as integer numerators.

[Syntax: DF=number] 
          
Specifies the degrees of freedom for the t-test.
Requests that the L matrix coefficients be displayed.

[Syntax: GROUP coeffs] 
          
Sets up random-effect contrasts between different groups when a GROUP variable 
appears in the RANDOM statement.

[Syntax: SINGULAR=number] 
          
Tunes the estimability checking.

[Syntax: SUBJECT coeffs] 
          
Sets up random-effect estimates between different subjects when a SUBJECT= variable 
appears in the RANDOM statement.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: LSMEANS fixed-effects </ options> ;
     
The LSMEANS statement computes least squares means (LS-means) of fixed effects.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Requests that t-type confidence limits be constructed for each of the LS-means.

Displays the estimated covariance matrix of the least squares means as part of the 
"Least Squares Means" table.
Requests that the L coefficients for all LSMEANS effects be displayed.

[Syntax: ALPHA=number] 
          
Requests that a t-type confidence interval be constructed for each of the LS-means 
with confidence level 1-number. The value of number must be between 0 and 1; the 
default is 0.05.

Displays the estimated correlation matrix of the least squares means as part of the 
"Least Squares Means" table.

[Syntax: DF=number] 
          
Specifies the degrees of freedom for the t test and confidence limits.

[Syntax: SINGULAR=number] 
          
Tunes the estimability checking.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: TEST fixed-effects </ options> ;  
      
By default, for each sum of squares in the analysis an F value is computed that uses the residual 
MS as an error term. Use a TEST statement to request additional F tests that use other effects as 
error terms.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: HTYPE=value-list] 
          
Indicates the type of hypothesis test to perform on the specified effects. Valid 
entries for values in the value-list are 3, corresponding to a Type III test. The 
default value is 3. The ODS table name is "Tests3" for the Type III test.
Requests that chi-square tests be performed in addition to any F tests.
Requests that matrix coefficients associated with test types be displayed for specified effects.
Requests that Type III matrix coefficients be displayed if a Type III test is performed.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: OUTPUT <OUT=SAS-data-set> <keyword<(keyword-options)><=name>>...
  <keyword<(keyword-options)> <=name>> </ options> ; 

where:

keyword<(keyword-options)> <=name> 
specifies a statistic to include in the output data set and optionally assigns the variable the name, name. 

The OUTPUT statement creates a data set that contains predicted values and residual diagnostics, 
computed after fitting the model. By default, all variables in the original data set are included 
in the output data set.      

You can use the keyword-options to control which type of a particular statistic to compute. 

The keyword-options can take on the following values: 

    BLUP 
    uses the predictors of the random effects in computing the statistic. 

    NOBLUP 
    does not use the predictors of the random effects in computing the statistic. 

    The default is to compute statistics by using BLUPs.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: OUT=SAS-data-set] 
          
Specifies the name of the output data set. If the OUT= (or DATA=) option is omitted, 
the procedure uses the DATAn convention to name the output data set.

Outputs the following statistic: 
          
PREDICTED<=name>
Linear predictor; default variable name: "Pred"

PREDICTED(NOBLUP)<=name>
Marginal linear predictor; default variable name: "PredPA"

Outputs the following statistic: 
          
STDERR<=name>
Standard deviation of linear predictor; default variable name: "StdErr"

STDERR(NOBLUP)<=name>
Standard deviation of marginal linear predictor; default variable name: "StdErrPA"

Outputs the following statistic: 
          
RESIDUAL<=name>
Residual; default variable name: "Resid"

RESIDUAL(NOBLUP)<=name>
Marginal residual; default variable name: "ResidPA"

Outputs the following statistic: 
          
PEARSON<=name>
Pearson-type residual; default variable name: "Pearson"

PEARSON(NOBLUP)<=name>
Marginal Pearson-type residual; default variable name: "PearsonPA"

Outputs the following statistic: 
          
STUDENT<=name>
Studentized residual; default variable name: "Student"

STUDENT(NOBLUP)<=name>
Studentized marginal residual; default variable name: "StudentPA"

Outputs the following statistic: 
          
LCL<=name>
Lower prediction limit for linear predictor; default variable name: "LCL"

LCL(NOBLUP)<=name>
Lower confidence limit for marginal linear predictor; default variable name: "LCLPA"

Outputs the following statistic: 
          
UCL<=name>
Upper prediction limit for linear predictor; default variable name: "UCL"

UCL(NOBLUP)<=name>
Upper confidence limit for marginal linear predictor; default variable name: "UCLPA"

Outputs the following statistic: 
          
VARIANCE<=name>
Conditional variance of pseudo-data; default variable name: "Variance"

VARIANCE(NOBLUP)<=name>
Marginal variance of pseudo-data; default variable name: "VariancePA"
Requests that all statistics are computed.

[Syntax: ALPHA=number] 
          
Determines the coverage probability for two-sided confidence and prediction intervals. 
The coverage probability is computed as 1-number. The value of number must be between 
0 and 1 inclusively; the default is 0.05.

Requests that records be written to the output data only for those observations that were used 
in the analysis.
Requests that names not be made unique in the case of naming conflicts.
Requests that variables from the input data set not be added to the output data set.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: RANDOM random-effects </ options> ; 
      
The RANDOM statement defines the random effects in the mixed model.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: ALPHA=number] 
          
Requests that a t-type confidence interval with confidence level 1-number be constructed 
for the predictors of random effects in this statement. The value of number must be 
between 0 and 1 exclusively; the default is 0.05

Requests that t-type confidence limits be constructed for each of the predictors of random effects 
in this statement.

[Syntax: GROUP=effect] 
          
Defines an effect specifying heterogeneity in the covariance structure of G.

Eliminates the columns in Z corresponding to missing levels of random effects involving CLASS variables. 
By default, these columns are included in Z. It is sufficient to specify the NOFULLZ option in any 
RANDOM statement.
Requests that the solution for the random-effects parameters be produced.

[Syntax: SUBJECT=effect] 
          
Identifies the subjects in your mixed model. Complete independence is assumed 
across subjects; thus, for the RANDOM statement, the SUBJECT= option produces 
a block-diagonal structure in G with identical blocks.

[Syntax: TYPE=covariance-structure] 
          
Specifies the covariance structure of G for G-side effects. The TYPE=VC (variance 
components) option is the default structure. Another structure available in this 
experimental release is CHOL.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: REPEATED <repeated-effect></ options> ;
      
The REPEATED statement defines the repeated effect and the residual covariance structure 
in the mixed model. The residual variance-covariance matrix is denoted as R. The repeated-
effect is required and consists entirely of classification variables. The levels of the 
repeated-effect must be different for each observation within a subject in order to avoid 
the singular R matrix. The SUBJECT= option is required. The data set must be grouped by 
subject effect.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: GROUP=effect] 
          
Defines an effect that specifies heterogeneity in the residual covariance structure. 
All observations that have the same level of the GROUP effect have the same covariance 
parameters. Each new level of the GROUP effect produces a new set of covariance parameters 
with the same structure as the original group. You should exercise caution in defining 
the GROUP effect, because strange covariance patterns can result with its misuse. Also, 
the GROUP effect can greatly increase the number of estimated covariance parameters, 
which can adversely affect the optimization process. 

Continuous variables are permitted as arguments to the GROUP= option. PROC HPMIXED 
does not sort by the values of the continuous variable; rather, it considers the 
data to be from a new subject or group whenever the value of the continuous variable 
changes from the previous observation. Using a continuous variable decreases execution 
time for models with a large number of subjects or groups and also prevents the 
production of a large "Class Level Information" table.

[Syntax: R<=value-list>] 
          
Requests that blocks of the estimated R matrix be displayed. The first block determined 
by the SUBJECT= effect is the default displayed block. 

The value-list indicates the subjects for which blocks of  are to be displayed. For 
example, the following statement displays block matrices for the first, third, and 
fifth persons: 

  repeated time / type=un subject=person r=1,3,5;

[Syntax: RC<=value-list>] 
          
Displays the Cholesky root of blocks of the estimated R matrix. The value-list 
specification is the same as for the R= option.

[Syntax: RCI<=value-list>] 
          
Displays the inverse Cholesky root of blocks of the estimated R matrix. The value-list 
specification is the same as for the R= option.

[Syntax: RCORR<=value-list>] 
          
Displays the correlation matrix that corresponds to blocks of the estimated R matrix. 
The value-list specification is the same as for the R= option.

[Syntax: RI<=value-list>] 
          
Produces the inverse of blocks of the estimated R matrix. The value-list specification 
is the same as for the R= option.

[Syntax: SUBJECT=effect] 
          
Identifies the subjects in your mixed model. Complete independence is assumed across subjects; 
therefore, the SUBJECT= option produces a block-diagonal structure in R with identical blocks. 
The SUBJECT= option is required. The data set must be grouped by SUBJECT= effect. When the 
SUBJECT= effect consists entirely of classification variables, the blocks of R correspond to 
observations that share the same level of that effect. These blocks are sorted according to 
this effect as well. 

Continuous variables are permitted as arguments to the SUBJECT= option. PROC HPMIXED 
does not sort by the values of the continuous variable; rather, it considers the data 
to be from a new subject or group whenever the value of the continuous variable changes 
from the previous observation. Using a continuous variable decreases execution time for 
models with a large number of subjects or groups and also prevents the production of a 
large "Class Level Information" table. 

If you want to model nonzero covariance among all of the observations in your data, 
pecify SUBJECT=INTERCEPT to treat the data as if they are all from one subject. However, 
be aware that in this case PROC HPMIXED manipulates an R matrix with dimensions equal 
to the number of observations.

[Syntax: TYPE=covariance-structure] 
          
Specifies the structure of the residual variance-covariance matrix R. The SUBJECT= option 
defines the blocks of R, and the TYPE= option specifies the structure of these blocks.

[Syntax: ABSCONV= | ABSTOL=r] 
          
Specifies an absolute function convergence criterion.

[Syntax: ABSFCONV=r <n>  | ABSFTOL=r<n>] 
          
Specifies an absolute function convergence criterion.

[Syntax: ABSGCONV= | ABSGTOL=r <n>] 
          
Specifies an absolute gradient convergence criterion. Termination requires the 
maximum absolute gradient element to be small.

[Syntax: ABSXCONV= | ABSXTOL=r <n>] 
          
Specifies the absolute parameter convergence criterion. Termination requires 
a small Euclidean distance between successive parameter vectors.

[Syntax: ASINGULAR | ASING=r] 
          
Specifies an absolute singularity criterion r, r > 0, for the inversion of 
the information matrix, which is needed to compute the covariance matrix.

[Syntax: DAMPSTEP | DS  <=r>] 
          
Specifies that the initial step-size value a⁰ for each line search (used by the 
QUANEW, CONGRA, or NEWRAP technique) cannot be larger than r times the step-size value 
used in the former iteration.

[Syntax: FCONV=r | FTOL=r] 
          
          
Specifies the relative function convergence criterion.

[Syntax: FCONV2= | FTOL2=r <n>] 
          
Specifies a second function convergence criterion.

[Syntax:FSIZE=r] 
          
Specifies the FSIZE parameter of the relative function and relative gradient 
termination criteria. The default value is r=0.

[Syntax: GCONV=r | GTOL=r] 
          
Specifies the relative gradient convergence criterion.

[Syntax: GCONV2=r | GTOL2=r] 
          
Specifies another relative gradient convergence criterion.

Specifies the scaling version of the Hessian or crossproduct Jacobian matrix used in NRRIDG, TRUREG, 
LEVMAR, NEWRAP, or DBLDOG optimization.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that no scaling is done.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies the Dennis, Gay, and Welsch (1981) scaling update
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies that di is reset in each iteration

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: INHESSIAN<=r>] 
          
Specifies how the initial estimate of the approximate Hessian is defined for 
the quasi-Newton techniques QUANEW and DBLDOG.

[Syntax: INSTEP=r] 
          
Reduces the length of the first trial step during the line search of the first iterations.

[Syntax: LCDEACT= | LCD=r] 
          
Specifies a threshold r for the Lagrange multiplier that decides whether an active 
inequality constraint remains active or can be deactivated.

[Syntax: LCEPSILON= | LCEPS= | LCE=r] 
          
Specifies the range r, r ≥ 0, for active and violated boundary and linear 
constraints.

[Syntax: LCSINGULAR= | LCSING= | LCS=r] 
          
Specifies a criterion r, r ≥ 0, used in the update of the QR decomposition that 
decides whether an active constraint is linearly dependent on a set of other 
active constraints.

[Syntax: LINESEARCH | LIS | SMETHOD | SM=i] 
          
Specifies the line-search method for the CONGRA, QUANEW, and NEWRAP optimization 
techniques.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies a line-search method that needs the same number of function and gradient calls for cubic  interpolation and cubic extrapolation;  this method is similar to one used by the Harwell subroutine library.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies a line-search method that needs more function calls than gradient calls for quadratic and  cubic interpolation and cubic extrapolation; this method is implemented as shown in Fletcher (1987)  and can be modified to an exact line search by using the LSPRECISION= option.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies a line-search method that needs the same number of function and gradient calls for cubic  interpolation and cubic extrapolation; this method is implemented as shown in Fletcher (1987) and can  be modified to an exact line search by using the LSPRECISION= option.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies a line-search method that needs the same number of function and gradient calls for stepwise  extrapolation and cubic interpolation
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Specifies a line-search method that is a modified version of LIS=4.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip6: Specifies golden section line search (Polak 1971), which uses only function values for linear approximation.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip7: Specifies bisection line search (Polak 1971), which uses only function values for linear approximation.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip8: Specifies Armijo line-search technique (Polak 1971), which uses only function values for linear approximation.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: LSPRECISION=r | LSP=r | SPRECISION=r | SP=r] 
          
Specifies the degree of accuracy that should be obtained by the line-search algorithms 
LIS=2 and LIS=3. The default LSPRECISION= values are:

  o For TECH=QUANEW UPDATE=DBFGS, BFGS: r = 0.4
  o For TECH=QUANEW UPDATE=DDFP, DFP: r = 0.06 
  o For TECH=CONGRA UPDATE=all r = 0.1
  o For TECH=NEWRAP NO UPDATE: r = 0.9

[Syntax: MAXFUNC=i | MAXFU=i] 
          
Requires the number of function calls to be no larger than i. The default values are: 

  o For TECH= LEVMAR, NEWRAP, NRRIDG, TRUREG: i=125 
  o For TECH= DBLDOG, QUANEW: i=500 
  o For TECH= CONGRA: i=1000

[Syntax: MAXITER= | MAXIT=i <n>] 
          
Requires the number of iterations to be no larger than i. The default values are:

  o For TECH= LEVMAR, NEWRAP, NRRIDG, TRUREG: i=50 
  o For TECH= DBLDOG, QUANEW: i=200 
  o For TECH= CONGRA: i=400

[Syntax: MAXSTEP=r<n>] 
          
Specifies an upper bound for the step length of the line-search algorithms during 
the first n iterations.

[Syntax: MAXTIME=r] 
          
Requires the CPU time to be no larger than r. The default value of the MAXTIME= 
option is the largest double floating-point number on your computer.

[Syntax: MINITER= | MINIT=i] 
          
Specifies the minimum number of iterations. The default value is 0.

[Syntax: MSINGULAR= | MSING=r] 
          
Specifies a relative singularity criterion r, r > 0, for the inversion of 
the information matrix, which is needed to compute the covariance matrix.
Suppresses output related to optimization such as the iteration history.
[Displays information about the starting values and final values of the optimization process.

Displays the optimization history. The PHISTORY option is set automatically if the PALL or PRINT 
option is set.

[Syntax: RESTART= | REST=i] 
          
Specifies that the QUANEW or CONGRA algorithm is restarted with a steepest descent/ascent 
search direction after at most i iterations, i > 0.

[Syntax: SINGULAR= | SING=r] 
          
Specifies the singularity criterion r, 0 < r < 1, used, for example, for matrix 
inversion.
Specifies the fileref that contains the information needed for remote monitoring.

[Syntax: TECHNIQUE= | TECH=name | OMETHOD= | OM=name] 
          
Specifies the optimization technique.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Chooses one of four different conjugate-gradient optimization algorithms, which can be more precisely  defined with the UPDATE= option and modified with the LINESEARCH= option.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Performs a version of double-dogleg optimization, which uses the gradient to update an approximation  of the Cholesky factor of the Hessian.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Performs a highly stable but, for large problems, memory- and time-consuming Levenberg-Marquardt  optimization technique, a slightly improved variant of the Moré (1978) implementation. This is  the default optimization technique if there are fewer than 40 parameters to estimate.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Performs a usually stable but, for large problems, memory- and time-consuming Newton-Raphson optimization  technique. The algorithm combines a line-search algorithm with ridging, and it can be modified with the  LINESEARCH= option.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Performs a usually stable but, for large problems, memory- and time-consuming Newton-Raphson  optimization technique. This algorithm does not perform a line search.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip6: Chooses one of four different quasi-Newton optimization algorithms that can be more precisely defined  with the UPDATE= option and modified with the LINESEARCH= option.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip7: Performs a usually very stable but, for large problems, memory- and time-consuming trust-region  optimization technique. The algorithm is implemented similar to Gay (1983) and Moré and Sorensen (1983).
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip8: Does not perform any optimization. This option is similar to METHOD=NONE, but TECH=NONE also computes  and displays residuals and goodness of fit statistics.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies the update method for the quasi-Newton, double-dogleg, or conjugate-gradient optimization technique.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Performs the original Broyden, Fletcher, Goldfarb, and Shanno (BFGS) update of the inverse Hessian matrix.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Performs the dual BFGS update of the Cholesky factor of the Hessian matrix. This is the default update method.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Performs the dual Davidon, Fletcher, and Powell (DFP) update of the Cholesky factor of the Hessian matrix.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Performs the original DFP update of the inverse Hessian matrix.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Performs the automatic restart update method of Powell (1977) and Beale (1972).
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip8: Performs a conjugate-descent update of Fletcher (1987).

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies the version of the quasi-Newton optimization technique with nonlinear constraints.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies the update of the U vector as in Powell (1978a, 1978b) (update like VF02AD).
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies the update of the U vector as in Powell (1982a, 1982b) (update like VMCWD).

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: VSINGULAR= | VSING=r] 
          
Specifies a relative singularity criterion r, r > 0, for the inversion of the 
information matrix, which is needed to compute the covariance matrix.

[Syntax: XCONV= | XTOL=r <n>] 
          
Specifies the relative parameter convergence criterion. Termination requires 
a small relative parameter change in subsequent iterations.

[Syntax: XSIZE=r] 
          
Specifies the XSIZE parameter of the relative function and relative gradient termination 
criteria. The default value is r=0.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: PARMS <(value-list)> ...</ options> ;
      
The PARMS statement specifies initial values for the covariance parameters, or it requests 
a grid search over several values of these parameters. You must specify the values in the 
order in which they appear in the "Covariance Parameter Estimates" table. 

The value-list specification can take any of several forms: 

  m 
  a single value 

  m1,m2,...,mn
  several values 

  m to n 
  a sequence where m equals the starting value, n equals the ending value, and the increment equals 1 

  m to n by i 
  a sequence where m equals the starting value, n equals the ending value, and the increment equals i 

  m1,m2 to m3
  mixed values and sequences 

You can use the PARMS statement to input known parameters.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: HOLD=value-list 
          
Specifies which parameter values PROC HPLMIXED should hold equal to the specified 
values. For example, the following statement constrains the first and third covariance 
parameters to equal 5 and 2, respectively:

    parms (5) (3) (2) (3) / hold=1,3;

Requests that no Newton-Raphson iterations be performed and that PROC HPLMIXED use the best value 
from the grid search to perform inferences. By default, iterations begin at the best value 
from the PARMS grid search.

Syntax: PARMSDATA=SAS-data-set 
          
Reads in covariance parameter values from a SAS data set. The data set should contain the Est or
Covp1–Covpn variables.

[Syntax: ALPHA=number] 
          
Requests that a t-type confidence interval be constructed for each of the fixed-effects 
parameters with confidence level 1-number. The value of number must be between 0 and 1; 
the default is 0.05.

Requests that t-type confidence limits be constructed for each of the fixed-effects 
parameter estimates.

[Syntax: DDF=value-list] 
          
Enables you to specify your own denominator degrees of freedom for the fixed effects.

Specifies the method for computing the denominator degrees of freedom for the tests 
of fixed effects resulting from the MODEL, CONTRAST, ESTIMATE, LSMEANS, and TEST 
statements.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Performs all tests by using the residual degrees of freedom, n-rank(X), where n  is the number of observations used.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that no denominator degrees of freedom be applied.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Requests that no intercept be included in the model. An intercept is included by default.
Requests that a solution for the fixed-effects parameters be produced.

[Syntax:ZETA=number] 
          
Tunes the sensitivity in forming Type III functions.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: EFFECT effect-name = effect-type (var-list < / effect-options >) ; 

The name of the effect is specified after the EFFECT keyword. This name can appear 
in only one EFFECT statement and cannot be the name of a variable in the input data 
set. The effect-type is specified after an equal sign, followed by a list of variables 
within parentheses which are used in constructing the effect. Effect-options that are 
specific to an effect-type can be specified after a slash (/) following the variable list. 

The EFFECT statement enables you to construct special collections of columns for design 
matrices. These collections are referred to as constructed effects to distinguish them 
from the usual model effects formed from continuous or classification variables.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Replace 'EFFECT-NAME' with the name of the effect, specified after the EFFECT keyword. 
This name can appear in only one EFFECT statement and cannot be the name of a 
variable in the input data set.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Is a collection effect that defines one or more variables as a single effect with  multiple degrees of freedom. The variables in a collection are considered as a  unit for estimation and inference.  Option(s) available (specified after a slash (/) following the variable list):   DETAILS  Displays the constituents of the collection effect
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Is a classification effect in which the level that is used for a given period  corresponds to the level in the preceding period.   Options available (specified after a slash (/) following the variable list):    DESIGNROLE=    Names a variable that controls to which lag design an observation is assigned     DETAILS    Displays the lag design of the lag effect     NLAG=    Specifies the number of periods in the lag     PERIOD=    Names the variable that defines the period     WITHIN=    Names the variable or variables that define the group within which each period is defined
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Is a multimember classification effect whose levels are determined by one or  more variables that appear in a CLASS statement.   Options available (specified after a slash (/) following the variable list):     NOEFFECT    Specifies that observations with all missing levels for the multimember variables should    have zero values in the corresponding design matrix columns     WEIGHT=    Specifies the weight variable for the contributions of each of the classification effects
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Is a multivariate polynomial effect in the specified numeric variables.                                      Options available (specified after a slash (/) following the variable list):     DEGREE=    Specifies the degree of the polynomial     MDEGREE=    Specifies the maximum degree of any variable in a term of the polynomial     STANDARDIZE=    Specifies centering and scaling suboptions for the variables that define the polynomial
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Is a regression spline effect whose columns are univariate spline expansions of  one or more variables. A spline expansion replaces the original variable with  an expanded or larger set of new variables.   Options available (specified after a slash (/) following the variable list):     BASIS=    Specifies the type of basis (B-spline basis or truncated power function basis) for the spline expansion     DEGREE=    Specifies the degree of the spline transformation     KNOTMETHOD=    Specifies how to construct the knots for spline effects

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[For the LAG effect-type only]
          
[Syntax: PERIOD=variable] 
          
Specifies the period variable of the LAG design. The number of periods is the number 
of unique formatted values of the PERIOD= variable, and the ordering of the period is 
formed by sorting these formatted values in ascending order. You must specify a PERIOD= 
variable.

[For the LAG effect-type only] 
          
[Syntax: WITHIN=(variables) | WITHIN=variable] 

Specifies a variable (or a list of variables within parentheses) that defines the 
subject grouping of the lag design. If there is only one WITHIN= variable, then the 
parentheses are not required. Each subject is defined by the unique set of formatted 
values of the variables in the WITHIN= list. The subjects are sorted in ascending 
lexicographic order. You must specify a WITHIN= variable.

[For the LAG effect-type only] 
          
[Syntax: DESIGNROLE=variable] 

Specifies a numeric variable that is used to subset observations into a fitting group 
in which the value of the DESIGNROW= variable is nonzero and a second group in which 
the value of the specified variable is zero. The observations in the fitting group are 
used to form the LAG design matrix that is used in fitting the model. The LAG design 
that corresponds to the non-fitting group is used when scoring observations in the 
input data set that do not belong to the fitting group. This option is useful when 
you want to obtain predicted values in an output data set for observations that are 
not used in fitting the model. If you do not specify a DESIGNROLE= variable, then all 
observations are assigned to the fitting group.

[For the LAG | COLLECTION | MULTIMEMBER | POLYNOMIAL |SPLINE effect-type] 
          
Requests a table that shows the (1) lag design matrix of the lag effect, or (2) constituents 
of the collection effect, or (3) levels of the multimember effect, or (4) details of the specified 
polynomial, or (5) knot locations and the knots associated with each spline basis function.

[For the LAG effect-type only] 
          
[Syntax: NLAG= n] 

Specifies the number of lags. By default NLAG=1.

[For the MULTIMEMBER effect-type only] 
          
Specifies that, for observations with all missing levels of the multimember variables, 
the values in the corresponding design matrix columns be set to zero.

[For the MULTIMEMBER effect-type only] 
          
Specifies that for each observation, the entries in the design matrix that corresponds 
to the multimember effect be scaled to have a sum of one.

[For the MULTIMEMBER effect-type only] 
          
[Syntax: WEIGHT=wght-list] 

Specifies numeric variables used to weigh the contributions of each of the classification 
effects that define the constructed multimember effect. The number of variables in wght-list 
must match the number of classification variables that define the effect.

[For the POLYNOMIAL and SPLINE effect-type only] 
          
[Syntax: DEGREE=n] 

Specifies the (1) degree of the polynomial, or (2) degree of the spline transformation. 
The degree must be a positive integer. The n degree is typically a small integer, such as 
1, 2, or 3. The default for polynomial effect is DEGREE=1, and DEGREE=3 for spline 
transformation.

[For the POLYNOMIAL effect-type only] 
          
[Syntax: LABELSTYLE=(style-opts) | LABELSTYLE=style-opt] 

Specifies how the terms in the polynomial are labeled. By default, powers are shown 
with ^ as the exponentiation operator and * as the multiplication operator.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that each variable with an exponent greater than 1 be written as products of that variable.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Syntax: EXPONENT <=quoted string>                                      Specifies that each variable with an exponent greater than 1 be written using exponential  notation. By default, the symbol ^ is used as the exponentiation operator. If you supply the  optional quoted string after an equal sign, then that string is used as the exponentiation  operator.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies that the name of the effect followed by an underscore be used as a prefix  for term labels.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Syntax: PRODUCTSYMBOL=NONE | quoted string                                      Specifies that the supplied string be used as the product symbol.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[For the POLYNOMIAL effect-type only] 
          
[Syntax: MDEGREE=n] 

Specifies the maximum degree of any variable in a term of the polynomial. This degree 
must be a positive integer. The default is the degree of the specified polynomial.

[For the POLYNOMIAL effect-type only] 
          
Specifies that the polynomial be treated as a single effect with multiple degrees 
of freedom. The effect name that you specify is used as the constructed effect name, 
and the labels of the terms are used as labels of the corresponding parameters.

[For the POLYNOMIAL effect-type only] 
          
[Syntax: STANDARDIZE <(centerscale-opts)> <= standardize-opt>] 

Specifies that the variables that define the polynomial be standardized. By default, 
the standardized variables receive prefix "s_" in the variable names. 

You can use the following centerscale-opts to specify how the center and scale are estimated: 

  METHOD=MOMENTS 
  specifies that the center be estimated by the variable mean and the scale be estimated by the standard deviation. 

  METHOD=RANGE 
  specifies that the center be estimated by the midpoint of the variable range and the scale be estimated as half the variable range.

  METHOD=WMOMENTS 
  is the same as METHOD=MOMENTS except that weighted means and weighted standard deviations are used. 

  PREFIX=NONE | quoted-string 
  specifies the prefix that is appended to standardized variables when forming the term labels.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that variables be centered but not scaled.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that variables be centered and scaled. This is the default if you do not  specify a standardization-opt.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies that no standardization be performed.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies that variables be scaled but not centered.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[For the SPLINE effect-type only] 
          
Specifies a basis for the spline expansion.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies a B-spline basis for the spline expansion.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Syntax: TPF(options)                                      Specifies a truncated power function basis for the spline expansion.   You can modify the number of columns when you request BASIS=TPF with the following options:     NOINT    excludes the intercept column.     NOPOWERS    excludes the intercept and polynomial columns.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[For the SPLINE effect-type only]
          
Specifies that the extremes of the data be used as boundary knots when building a B-spline basis.

[For the SPLINE effect-type only]
          
[Syntax: KNOTMAX=value] 

Specifies that, for each variable in the EFFECT statement, the right-side boundary 
knots be equally spaced starting at the maximum of the variable and ending at the 
specified value. This option is ignored for variables whose maximum value is greater 
than the specified value or if the DATABOUNDARY option is also specified.

[For the SPLINE effect-type only] 
          
Specifies how to construct the knots for spline effects.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Syntax: EQUAL<(n)>               Specifies that n equally spaced knots be positioned between the extremes of the data.  The default is n=3. For a B-spline basis, any needed boundary knots continue to be  equally spaced unless the DATABOUNDARY option has also been specified. KNOTMETHOD=EQUAL  is the default if no knot-method is specified.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Syntax: LIST(number-list)                                      Specifies the list of internal knots to be used in forming the spline basis columns.  For a B-spline basis, the data extremes are used as boundary knots.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Syntax: LISTWITHBOUNDARY(number-list)                                      Specifies the list of all knots that are used in forming the spline basis columns.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Syntax: MULTISCALE<(multiscale-options)>                                      Specifies that multiple B-spline bases be generated, corresponding to sets with an  increasing number of internal knots.   You can control which scales are included with the following multiscale-options:     STARTSCALE=n    specifies the start scale, where n is a positive integer. The default is STARTSCALE=0.     ENDSCALE=n    specifies the end scale, where n is a positive integer. The default is ENDSCALE=7.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Syntax: PERCENTILES(n)                                      Requests that internal knots be placed at n equally spaced percentiles of the variable  or variables named in the EFFECT statement.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip6: Syntax: RANGEFRACTIONS(fraction-list)                                      Requests that internal knots be placed at each fraction of the ranges of the variables  in the EFFECT statement.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[For the SPLINE effect-type only] 
          
[Syntax: KNOTMIN=value] 

Specifies that for each variable in the EFFECT statement, the left-side boundary knots be 
equally spaced starting at the specified value and ending at the minimum of the variable. 
This option is ignored for variables whose minimum value is less than the specified value 
or if the DATABOUNDARY option is also specified.

[For the SPLINE effect-type only] 
          
Specifies that when multiple variables are specified in the EFFECT statement, 
the spline basis for each variable be treated as a separate effect. The names 
of these separated effects are formed by appending an underscore followed by 
the name of the variable to the name that you specify in the EFFECT statement.

[For the SPLINE effect-type only] 
          
Specifies that each individual column in the design matrix that corresponds to the spline 
effect be treated as a separate effect that can enter or leave the model independently. 
Names for these split effects are generated by appending the variable name and an index 
for each column to the name that you specify in the EFFECT statement.
